The day the Assemblée Nationale passed a far-right bill
subhead: On Thursday, October 30, MPs in the Assemblée Nationale passed, by just a single vote, a resolution put forward by the far-right Rassemblement National party, aimed at condemning a 1968 French-Algerian agreement.

Ceasefires in Gaza and Lebanon both favor Israel
subhead: In both cases, Israel has imposed a situation that more closely resembles a de-escalation or low-intensity conflict. But Israeli violations of the Gaza ceasefire have resulted in far more deaths.

title: French justice minister visits Nicolas Sarkozy in jail, sparking political firestorm
subhead: Minister Gérald Darmanin, a former protégé of Sarkozy, visited the ex-president at La Santé prison on Wednesday. Judges condemned the visit as favoritism and a violation of France's separation of powers.

title: At the Musée d'Orsay, painter Bridget Riley's journey from Neo-Impressionism to abstraction
subhead: A thought-provoking exhibition explores how the British artist incorporated Seurat's compositions into her own artistic investigations.

title: Egypt opens Grand Egyptian Museum, centerpiece of its tourism industry
subhead: The colossal project dates back to the 1990s. The huge site, next to the pyramids of Giza, is billed as the largest museum in the world dedicated to a single civilization. It opens on November 1 after years of delays.

'Airbnb has shaped the idea that everything can be monetized. It's a logic of constant optimization'
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (2/6). In Paris, about one-third of the listings available on Airbnb have been removed from the 'permanent' housing market, which contributes to the housing crisis in the French capital, explains researcher Jeanne Richon in an interview with Le Monde.

title: 'You can see poverty spreading': France's welfare services confront growing hardship
subhead: Around France, agents of the CAF, a government body that provides welfare benefits, deal with difficult situations as social precarity increases.

title: Too old to get a job, too young to retire: The French women over 50 stuck in limbo
subhead: In France, 21% of people aged 55-61 struggle to find work but are unable to retire. Women, who suffer more from societal inequalities throughout their career, are particularly at risk.
